sub_title: Associate professor at African Studies Centre Leiden
summary: As an associate professor and senior researcher at the African Studies Centre Leiden, I employ life-course and intergenerational perspectives to increase understanding of regional and cyclical dynamics of conflict in Africa, particularly in the Great Lakes Region. I take a cultural anthropology perspective in my work and build on collaborations with colleagues in migration studies, medical anthropology and psychology to come to new insights in long-term effects of conflict on young people. In particular, I seek to identify how young people give shape to their own lives and societies, and what this means for ongoing conflict-peace dynamics.

education.field_of_study: Cultural Anthropology and Sociology of Non-western Societies

projects.title: Pedagogies of peace and conflict in the Great Lakes region
projects.description:
In this project we investigate how experiences of conflict, genocide and displacement of caregivers shape informal family pedagogies. Through family visits and interviews with caregivers and children we seek to identify how new generations learn to expect, accept, re-enact and resist parental messages about war and peace. Doing so, we hope to understand how ordinary, local people contribute to war and peace dynamics, as well to gauge how conflict may affect culture and society over the generations. 

We conduct the study in collaboration with the Mental Health and Behaviour research group of the University of Rwanda.

projects.title: Fearing the Violence to Come
projects.description: The focus in this project is on how memories – personal and communal – of  past violence in Burundi affect anticipations of new forms of violence, and how that affects the ways in which people act in times of uncertainty and unrest. By addressing how past experiences of violence feed into anticipation of violence and subsequent action, we contribute to understanding the role of imagination in the strategies of people to escape violence, adopt violence and/or seek peaceful alternatives. We thus explore a conflict as it unfolds and describe in more detail the mechanisms that feed into new cycles of violence, ‘othering’ and exile or those may help break these negative processes.

projects.title: Breaking the Cycle of Violence in Post-conflict Settings: The Potential of Community-Based Sociotherapy in Rwanda
projects.description: In this project we primarily focus on disturbed family dynamics generated by mass violence and its aftermath, its potential negative impact on the 'next generations', and the potential of community-based sociotherapy programme to prevent this. The insights will contribute to better understandings of the consquences of mass violence for future generations and provide policy-relevant tools for redesigning existing strategies to prevent the cycle of violence and ensure emotional and social well-being.

projects.title: The Intergenerational Transmission of Violence and Resilience in Burundi
projects.description:
This project aimed to understand how children in conflict-affected Burundi are confronted with and may start to reproduce violence throughout the various stages of their lives. We conducted ethnographic, narrative and epidemiological research to identify pertinent mechanisms n the school, family and community environment that foster the reproduction of violence. 

Besides 2 UNICEF policy briefs, 6 presentations, one round-table discussion and two symposia with Burundian and international stakeholders, the project resulted in 5 research reports co-published by UNICEF and the University of Amsterdam. We are currently in the process of preparing academic publications based on the results.

The project was part of the Peacebuilding, Education and Advocacy Programme (2012-2016), funded by the Netherlands Ministry of Foreign Affairs.

projects.description: In this project we investigate how experiences with conflict, genocide and displacement shape informal family pedagogies among refugee and Rwandan families in Rwanda. Taking the perspective of parents and children, we ask how nee generations come to accept, endure, resist and re-enact parental dispositions to conflict and peace. The project is conducted in collaboration with the Mental Health and Behaviour research group at University of Rwanda.
